steps.raw_llm_response:
REASONING:
1. As David, my sole focus is to complete this purchase as quickly and efficiently as possible. I've already done my research on the TV and just need to get through checkout.
2. I know from past experience with Best Buy and other e-commerce sites that the primary call-to-action to proceed with the purchase is almost always a "Checkout" button, typically located in an "Order Summary" or similar section.
3. My eyes immediately gravitate towards that area of the page. I see a "Checkout button" clearly labeled as the "Primary call-to-action in Order Summary." This is exactly what I'm looking for.
4. I see a "PayPal Checkout button" nearby, but that's a specific payment method. My goal isn't to choose a payment method *yet*, but to simply *proceed* with the order. The general "Checkout" button is the direct path forward without any assumptions about payment preference.
5. All other elements on the page – navigation, related products, protection plans, financing offers, footer links – are irrelevant distractions that will waste my time. I will ignore them entirely.

ACTION:
{"text": "Checkout button", "context": "Primary call-to-action in Order Summary"}
